column4: i have a ubuntu 11.04 running, which uses 200gb of my hdd, the rest of the hdd is used by other OS's. Now i want to add a new partition to ubuntu e.g /opt/vmware, is there any guide for this?
go grab gparted, it's a graphical tool that makes life easy
could i allocate my ntfs file system with gparted and make it ext4?
it'll let you resize partitions, and if you're not already using 4 primary partitions, you can make an extended partition which can contain many partitions inside it
but make sure you back up first, resizing is always risky
automatic sucks, make a /, /tmp, swap  and /home
and that covers most use cases on the desktop
another question: i didnt used linux for 2 years. back then it was possible to encrypt partitions while installing Ubuntu/Debian, i didnt see this option in 11.04.
did this change came along with ext4?
encrypting entire partitions should be avoided, it's in 90% of cases unnecessary
with exception to swap and /tmp which can do with random keys/reformat on boot
hm kk, so its not possible to encrypt everything except /boot?
it is technically, but it's stupid to
one gains no benefit from it because most of the data in /usr /var etc. it all OS data and is not private, nor gains any integrity from encryption
/home, /tmp and swap are the only things that really need encryption and /home/* is handled OOTB in the best way going
